docs.title: Welcome to Amazon Web Service Notes
docs.text:
Welcome to the AWS notes, your go-to resource for understanding Amazon Web Services. For detailed and official documentation, visit the Amazon Web Service Documentation Page.

  1. Quick Guide: Get started with a concise guide to AWS services and features. This section will provide an overview of key concepts and practical tips to help you navigate AWS effectively.

Explore the guide to gain insights into AWS and make the most of its cloud offerings!

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a comprehensive cloud computing platform provided by Amazon. It offers a broad range of cloud services including computing power, storage options, and networking capabilities. AWS is widely used for scalable applications, data processing, and enterprise solutions.

docs.title: What is Amazon Web Services?
docs.text: Amazon Web Services is a cloud platform offering a variety of services including computing power, storage, and databases. It enables users to build, deploy, and manage applications through Amazon's global network of data centers.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Scalability: Easily scale resources up or down based on demand.
  • Global Reach: Data centers around the world ensure low-latency access.
  • Security: Advanced security features and compliance certifications.
  • Flexibility: Support for various programming languages, frameworks, and tools.

docs.title: Compute Services
docs.text:
• Amazon EC2: Scalable virtual servers in the cloud.
  • AWS Lambda: Serverless computing service for running code without provisioning servers.
  • Amazon ECS: Managed container service for running Docker containers.

docs.title: Storage Services
docs.text:
• Amazon S3: Object storage for scalable storage of unstructured data.
  • Amazon EBS: Block storage for Amazon EC2 instances.
  • Amazon Glacier: Low-cost archival storage for long-term data backup.

docs.title: Database Services
docs.text:
• Amazon RDS: Managed relational database service for SQL databases.
  • Amazon DynamoDB: Managed NoSQL database service.
  • Amazon Aurora: High-performance relational database compatible with MySQL and PostgreSQL.

docs.title: Monitoring and Management
docs.text:
• Amazon CloudWatch: Monitoring service for AWS resources and applications.
  • AWS CloudTrail: Service that enables governance, compliance, and operational auditing.

docs.title: Launching an EC2 Instance
docs.text: Amazon EC2 allows you to create and manage virtual servers in the cloud.

docs.title: Example: Launching a New EC2 Instance using AWS CLI
docs.text:
aws ec2 run-instances \
  --image-id ami-0abcdef1234567890 \
  --count 1 \
  --instance-type t2.micro \
  --key-name my-key-pair \
  --security-group-ids sg-0123456789abcdef0 \
  --subnet-id subnet-0123456789abcdef0

docs.title: Storing and Retrieving Data
docs.text: Amazon S3 provides scalable object storage for unstructured data.

docs.title: Example: Uploading a File to S3
docs.text: aws s3 cp local-file.txt s3://my-bucket/

docs.title: Example: Downloading a File from S3
docs.text: aws s3 cp s3://my-bucket/remote-file.txt local-directory/

docs.title: Managing Relational Databases
docs.text: Amazon RDS is a managed relational database service for various SQL databases.

docs.title: Example: Creating an RDS Instance
docs.text:
aws rds create-db-instance \
  --db-instance-identifier mydbinstance \
  --db-instance-class db.t2.micro \
  --engine mysql \
  --master-username admin \
  --master-user-password password \
  --allocated-storage 20

docs.title: Example: Connecting to an RDS Database
docs.text: mysql -h mydbinstance.c9akciq32.rds.amazonaws.com -u admin -p

docs.title: Creating Serverless Functions
docs.text: AWS Lambda allows you to run code in response to events without managing servers.

docs.title: Example: Creating a Lambda Function
docs.text:
aws lambda create-function \
  --function-name my-function \
  --runtime python3.8 \
  --role arn:aws:iam::123456789012:role/service-role/my-role \
  --handler lambda_function.lambda_handler \
  --zip-file fileb://function.zip

docs.title: Example: Lambda Function Code (Python)
docs.text:
def lambda_handler(event, context):
    return {
        'statusCode': 200,
        'body': 'Hello, world!'
    }

docs.title: Managing Docker Containers
docs.text: Amazon ECS is a managed container service for running Docker containers.

docs.title: Example: Creating an ECS Cluster
docs.text: aws ecs create-cluster --cluster-name my-cluster

docs.title: Example: Running a Task
docs.text:
aws ecs run-task \
  --cluster my-cluster \
  --task-definition my-task-definition

docs.title: Monitoring AWS Resources
docs.text: Amazon CloudWatch provides monitoring and logging for AWS resources and applications.

docs.title: Example: Creating a CloudWatch Alarm
docs.text:
aws cloudwatch put-metric-alarm \
  --alarm-name my-alarm \
  --metric-name CPUUtilization \
  --namespace AWS/EC2 \
  --statistic Average \
  --period 300 \
  --threshold 80 \
  --comparison-operator GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold \
  --evaluation-periods 1 \
  --alarm-actions arn:aws:sns:us-east-1:123456789012:my-topic

docs.title: Using the AWS Command Line Interface
docs.text: The AWS CLI is a tool to manage AWS services from the command line.

docs.title: Example: Installing AWS CLI
docs.text:
curl "https://d1uj6qtbmh3dt5.cloudfront.net/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install

docs.title: Example: Configuring AWS CLI
docs.text: aws configure

docs.title: Example: Listing EC2 Instances
docs.text: aws ec2 describe-instances

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This document provides an overview of Amazon Web Services (AWS), including key services such as Amazon EC2, S3, RDS, Lambda, ECS, and CloudWatch. It includes examples for common tasks and commands to help you get started with AWS.
